issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.customfield_12310192: DistributedFileSystem#listStatusIterator(..) throws FileNotFoundException if directory got deleted during iterating over large list beyond ls limit.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
DFS#listStatusIterator(..) currently stops iterating silently when the directory gets deleted before fetching the next batch of entries.

It should throw FileNotFoundException() and let user know that file is deleted in the middle.
fields.summary: DFS#listStatusIterator(..) should throw FileNotFoundException if the directory deleted before fetching next batch of entries

This message was automatically generated.

Could you add an extra couple of lines on this topic in the concurrency expectations of listStatus in hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/site/markdown/filesystem/filesystem.md ? It covers changes in the dir being listed, but left out what happens if the dir itself goes away.

Thanks [~stevel@apache.org] for review.

There was no section for "FileSystem#listStatusIterator()". I have updated the doc in generic 'Concurrency and the Remote Iterator' section.

Please review.

seams reasonable; some minor nits to tune

# It may be misleading to say "File" in the FNFE text. Just say "Path" and let the user workout what was there
# test the next() call too
# switch to LambdaTestUtils.intercept() for those exception raising tests

{code}
intercept(FileNotFoundException.class, () -> itor.hasNext())
intercept(FileNotFoundException.class, () -> itor.next())
{code}
Hi folks, should we revive this one? I'm hoping to get all incompatible changes in before beta1 so alpha3->beta1 is smooth.
I see also that Rakesh +1'd non-binding before, but now his +1's are binding :)
OK, but I'd like the test to include the coverage; there are two ways of iterating: call hasNext() & next(). or just call next() until something fails, see
Updated the patch with extra assertions as mentioned by [~stevel@apache.org]. Sorry for the delayed update.
